ground_truth: Potter is lighting a big cigar which he has just given George, and the goon is beside Potter's chair, as usual. George drops his cigar on his lap and nervously brushes off the sparks from his clothes. As they shake hands, George feels a physical revulsion because Potter's hand feels like a cold mackerel to him. In that moment of physical contact, he knows he could never be associated with this man and drops his hand with a shudder. He peers intently into Potter's face, turns, and shouts at the goon, impassive as ever beside Potter's wheelchair. As George opens the office door to exit, he shouts at Mr. Potter's secretary in the outer office. The room is modestly furnished with just a cheap bed, a chair or two, and a dresser. Mary is asleep in the bed. As George comes in, his head is filled with many confusing thoughts relating to incidents in his past life. George takes off his hat and coat, moves over to the dresser, and stares at his reflection in the mirror. While the above thoughts are passing through George's head, his attention is caught by a picture on the wall near the dresser, which is the sketch of George lassoing the moon that we first saw in Mary's living room. Mary is now awake and starts singing their theme song. George crosses over and sits on the edge of the bed, and Mary nods her head happily. Over the following series of shots, we hear the voices of Joseph and Clarence in Heaven. George is crossing the street, heading for the offices of the Building and Loan. Mary is sitting on the floor playing with a baby, and a little boy is in a playpen nearby. Mary is busy hanging wallpaper and painting the old place. George has just come into the hall. He is obviously tired and discouraged as he starts up the stairs, and the knob on the banister comes off in his hand. A group of men, obviously just drafted, are marching along in a camp. Mrs. Bailey and other women in Red Cross uniforms are busily sewing, etc. Mary, with a portable U.S.O. pushcart, is serving coffee and doughnuts to men leaning from the train. Sam Wainwright is showing a set of blueprints to two Army officers. Potter is wheeled in toward a long table around which several men are seated. Gower and Uncle Billy are conducting a bond rally from the top of an Army tank. Bert, in uniform, is moving cautiously with a fixed bayonet, and there are smoke and flashes of gunfire in the background. Hundreds of planes are flying overhead with parachutes dropping from them. Marty is in the foreground, beckoning to soldiers to come on, and Harry is fastening the helmet of his flying clothes.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Potter is igniting a large stogie which he has just handed George, and the thug is next to Potter's chair, as usual. George lets his stogie fall on his lap and anxiously sweeps off the embers from his attire. As they clasp hands, George senses a bodily aversion because Potter's hand feels like a frigid mackerel to him. In that moment of bodily interaction, he knows he could never be connected with this man and drops his hand with a tremor. He gazes fixedly into Potter's visage, turns, and yells at the thug, unflinching as ever beside Potter's wheelchair. As George opens the office door to leave, he yells at Mr. Potter's secretary in the outer office. The room is simply outfitted with just a cheap bed, a seat or two, and a bureau. Mary is asleep in the bed. As George enters, his mind is filled with many perplexing ideas relating to occurrences in his prior life. George removes his hat and coat, moves over to the bureau, and gazes at his image in the mirror. While the above ideas are passing through George's mind, his attention is snared by a picture on the wall near the bureau, which is the illustration of George lassoing the moon that we first saw in Mary's living room. Mary is now awake and begins crooning their theme tune. George crosses over and sits on the edge of the bed, and Mary nods her head joyfully. Over the following sequence of shots, we hear the voices of Joseph and Clarence in Heaven. George is crossing the roadway, heading for the offices of the Building and Loan. Mary is sitting on the floor playing with an infant, and a little lad is in a playpen nearby. Mary is busy hanging wallpaper and painting the old dwelling. George has just come into the corridor. He is clearly weary and disheartened as he starts up the stairs, and the knob on the balustrade comes off in his hand. A group of men, evidently just enlisted, are marching along in a camp. Mrs. Bailey and other women in Red Cross uniforms are busily stitching, etc. Mary, with a portable U.S.O. cart, is serving coffee and doughnuts to men leaning from the train. Sam Wainwright is displaying a set of blueprints to two Army officers. Potter is wheeled in toward a long table around which several men are seated. Gower and Uncle Billy are conducting a bond rally from the top of an Army tank. Bert, in uniform, is moving cautiously with a fixed bayonet, and there are smoke and flashes of gunfire in the backdrop. Hundreds of aircraft are flying overhead with parachutes dropping from them. Marty is in the foreground, gesturing to soldiers to come on, and Harry is fastening the helmet of his flying apparel.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Potter is lighting a big cigar which has just been given to George by him, and Potter's chair is occupied by the goon, as usual. George's lap has a cigar dropped on it by him, and the sparks from his clothes are nervously brushed off by him. As hands are shaken, a physical revulsion is felt by George because Potter's hand is felt like a cold mackerel by him. In that moment of physical contact, he knows he could never associate himself with this man and his hand is dropped with a shudder by him. Potter's face is peered into intently by him, he turns, and the impassive goon is shouted at by him, who remains ever beside Potter's wheelchair. As the office door is opened by George to exit, Mr. Potter's secretary in the outer office is shouted at by him. A modest furnishing is seen in the room with just a cheap bed, a chair or two, and a dresser. Mary is asleep in the bed. As George comes in, many confusing thoughts relating to incidents in his past life fill his head. George's hat and coat are taken off by him, the dresser is moved over to by him, and his reflection in the mirror is stared at by him. While the above thoughts are passing through George's head, a picture on the wall near the dresser catches his attention, which is the sketch of George lassoing the moon first seen in Mary's living room. Mary is now awake and their theme song is started by her. George crosses over and the edge of the bed is sat on by him, and Mary's head is nodded happily by her. Over the following series of shots, the voices of Joseph and Clarence are heard by us in Heaven. George crosses the street, heading for the offices of the Building and Loan. Mary sits on the floor playing with a baby, and a little boy is in a playpen nearby. Mary busily hangs wallpaper and paints the old place. George has just come into the hall. Tiredness and discouragement are obvious in him as the stairs are started up, and the knob on the banister comes off in his hand. A camp is marched along by a group of men, obviously just drafted. Mrs. Bailey and other women busily sew, etc., in Red Cross uniforms. Mary, with a portable U.S.O. pushcart, serves coffee and doughnuts to men leaning from the train. A set of blueprints is shown to two Army officers by Sam Wainwright. Potter is wheeled in toward a long table around which several men are seated. A bond rally is conducted by Gower and Uncle Billy from the top of an Army tank. Bert, in uniform, moves cautiously with a fixed bayonet, and smoke and flashes of gunfire are in the background. Hundreds of planes fly overhead with parachutes dropping from them. Marty is in the foreground, beckoning to soldiers to come on, and Harry fastens the helmet of his flying clothes.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Potter lights a big cigar for George, with the goon beside his chair. George drops the cigar on his lap, nervously brushing off sparks. Shaking hands, George feels revulsion as Potter's hand is cold like a mackerel. Realizing he can't associate with Potter, he drops his hand, shuddering. He peers at Potter, then shouts at the goon and Mr. Potter's secretary. The modest room has a cheap bed, a chair, and a dresser. Mary sleeps in the bed. George enters, filled with confusing thoughts from his past. He removes his hat and coat, stares at his reflection, and notices a picture of him lassoing the moon, first seen in Mary's living room. Mary awakens, singing their theme song. George sits on the bed's edge, and Mary nods happily. Voices of Joseph and Clarence in Heaven are heard. George crosses the street to the Building and Loan offices. Mary plays with a baby, a little boy in a playpen nearby. She's busy with wallpaper and painting. George enters the hall, tired and discouraged, and the banister knob comes off in his hand. Drafted men march in a camp. Mrs. Bailey and other women in Red Cross uniforms sew. Mary serves coffee and doughnuts from a U.S.O. pushcart to men on a train. Sam Wainwright shows blueprints to Army officers. Potter is wheeled to a table with several men. Gower and Uncle Billy conduct a bond rally from an Army tank. Bert, in uniform, moves cautiously with a bayonet, smoke and gunfire in the background. Planes fly overhead, dropping parachutes. Marty beckons soldiers, and Harry fastens his flying helmet.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Potter lights a cigar for George, with the goon beside him. George drops the cigar, brushes off sparks, and feels revulsion shaking Potter's cold hand. He shudders, peers at Potter, and shouts at the goon. Exiting, he yells at Potter's secretary. The modest room has a bed, chair, and dresser. Mary sleeps as George enters, lost in past thoughts. He removes his hat and coat, stares in the mirror, and notices a moon-lassoing sketch. Mary awakens, sings their song, and George sits on the bed. Voices of Joseph and Clarence are heard. George crosses the street to the Building and Loan. Mary plays with a baby, hangs wallpaper, and paints. George, tired, enters, and the banister knob comes off. Drafted men march in camp. Mrs. Bailey and women sew in Red Cross uniforms. Mary serves coffee and doughnuts from a U.S.O. cart. Sam Wainwright shows blueprints to Army officers. Potter is wheeled to a table with men. Gower and Uncle Billy lead a bond rally on an Army tank. Bert, in uniform, moves with a bayonet amid smoke and gunfire. Planes fly overhead, dropping parachutes. Marty beckons soldiers, and Harry fastens his helmet.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Potter, with a deliberate and practiced motion, is in the process of lighting a large, impressive cigar, which he has just handed to George. The ever-present goon stands loyally beside Potter's chair, maintaining his usual position. In a moment of clumsiness, George accidentally drops his cigar onto his lap and hurriedly brushes off the sparks that threaten to ignite his clothing. As they engage in a handshake, George experiences a visceral sense of revulsion, as Potter's hand feels to him like a cold, lifeless mackerel. In that brief moment of physical contact, George realizes with certainty that he could never align himself with this man, and he releases Potter's hand with a noticeable shudder. He peers intently into Potter's face, then abruptly turns and shouts at the goon, who remains as impassive as ever beside Potter's wheelchair. As George opens the office door to make his exit, he directs a shout at Mr. Potter's secretary, who is stationed in the outer office. The room he enters is modestly furnished, containing only a cheap bed, a couple of chairs, and a dresser. Mary is peacefully asleep in the bed. As George enters, his mind is a whirlwind of confusing thoughts, all related to various incidents from his past life. He removes his hat and coat, moves over to the dresser, and gazes at his reflection in the mirror. While these thoughts are swirling through George's mind, his attention is drawn to a picture on the wall near the dresser. It is the sketch of George lassoing the moon, a familiar image first seen in Mary's living room. Mary, now awake, begins to sing their theme song softly. George crosses over to her and sits gently on the edge of the bed, and Mary nods her head happily in response. Over the subsequent series of shots, the voices of Joseph and Clarence can be heard from Heaven. George is seen crossing the street, making his way toward the offices of the Building and Loan. Meanwhile, Mary is sitting on the floor, playing with a baby, while a little boy is nearby in a playpen. Mary is busily engaged in hanging wallpaper and painting the old place. George has just entered the hall, looking visibly tired and discouraged as he begins to ascend the stairs. The knob on the banister unexpectedly comes off in his hand. A group of men, clearly just drafted, are marching in formation at a camp. Mrs. Bailey and other women, dressed in Red Cross uniforms, are busily sewing and attending to various tasks. Mary, with a portable U.S.O. pushcart, is serving coffee and doughnuts to men leaning out from the train. Sam Wainwright is enthusiastically showing a set of blueprints to two attentive Army officers. Potter is wheeled in toward a long table, around which several men are seated, ready for discussion. Gower and Uncle Billy are energetically conducting a bond rally from atop an Army tank. Bert, dressed in uniform, is moving cautiously with a fixed bayonet, while smoke and flashes of gunfire create a dramatic backdrop. Hundreds of planes are soaring overhead, with parachutes descending from them. Marty is prominently in the foreground, beckoning to soldiers to advance, and Harry is in the process of fastening the helmet of his flying clothes.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Potter, with a deliberate and practiced motion that he has likely perfected over the years, is currently in the process of lighting a large, impressive cigar, which he has just handed over to George. Ever-present and unwavering, the loyal goon stands steadfastly beside Potter's chair, maintaining his usual position as if it were a duty he takes pride in. In a moment of unexpected clumsiness, George accidentally drops his cigar onto his lap and hurriedly brushes off the errant sparks that threaten to ignite his clothing, a moment of panic flashing across his face. As they engage in a handshake, George experiences a visceral sense of revulsion, for Potter's hand feels to him quite unsettlingly like a cold, lifeless mackerel. In that brief moment of physical contact, George realizes with certainty that he could never align himself with this man, and he releases Potter's hand with a noticeable shudder, unable to hide his distaste. He peers intently into Potter's face for a moment, then abruptly turns and shouts at the ever-impassive goon, who remains as expressionless as ever beside Potter's wheelchair. As George opens the office door to make his exit, he directs a shout at Mr. Potter's secretary, who is dutifully stationed in the outer office. The room he enters is modestly furnished, containing only a cheap bed, a couple of chairs, and a dresser, each piece showing signs of wear. Mary, meanwhile, is peacefully asleep in the bed, her breathing steady. As George enters, his mind becomes a whirlwind of confusing thoughts, all related to various incidents from his past life. He removes his hat and coat, moves over to the dresser, and gazes at his reflection in the mirror, searching for answers. While these thoughts are swirling through George's mind, his attention is drawn to a picture on the wall near the dresser. It is the familiar sketch of George lassoing the moon, an image he first saw in Mary's living room. Mary, now awake, begins to softly sing their theme song. George crosses over to her and sits gently on the edge of the bed, and Mary nods her head happily in joyful response. Over the subsequent series of shots, the voices of Joseph and Clarence carry from Heaven, providing a celestial commentary. George is seen crossing the street, making his determined way toward the offices of the Building and Loan. Meanwhile, Mary is sitting on the floor, playing with a baby, while a little boy is nearby in a playpen. Mary is busily and energetically engaged in hanging wallpaper and painting the old place. George has just entered the hall, looking visibly tired and discouraged as he begins to ascend the stairs, each step feeling heavier than the last. The knob on the banister unexpectedly comes off in his hand, adding to his frustration. A group of men, who have clearly just been drafted, are marching in formation at a camp. Mrs. Bailey and other women, dressed in their Red Cross uniforms, are busily sewing and attending to various tasks with dedicated focus. Mary, with a portable U.S.O. pushcart, is serving coffee and doughnuts to men leaning out from the train, her smile adding warmth to the moment. Sam Wainwright is enthusiastically showing a detailed set of blueprints to two attentive Army officers. Potter is wheeled in toward a long table, around which several men are already seated, ready for the discussion to commence. Gower and Uncle Billy are energetically conducting a bond rally from atop an Army tank, their voices rising to inspire. Bert, dressed in uniform, is moving cautiously, a fixed bayonet in hand, while smoke and flashes of gunfire create a dramatic, intense backdrop. Hundreds of planes are soaring overhead, with parachutes gracefully descending from them. Marty is prominently in the foreground, beckoning urgently to soldiers to advance, and Harry is in the process of fastening the helmet of his flying clothes, preparing for whatever lies ahead.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Potter, seated comfortably in his chair, is in the process of lighting a large cigar, which he has just handed to George. The goon, ever-present and vigilant, stands beside Potter's chair, maintaining his usual position. As George attempts to enjoy the cigar, he accidentally drops it onto his lap, causing him to react quickly and nervously brush off the sparks that have landed on his clothes. In the midst of this, George extends his hand to shake Potter's, but as their hands meet, he is overcome with a strong sense of physical revulsion, likening the sensation to touching a cold mackerel. This moment of contact solidifies George's realization that he could never align himself with Potter, prompting him to abruptly release Potter's hand with a shudder. He then fixes his gaze intently on Potter's face, trying to comprehend the man before him, before turning away and shouting at the goon, who remains impassive and unmoved beside Potter's wheelchair. With a sense of urgency, George opens the office door to make his exit, raising his voice to shout at Mr. Potter's secretary in the outer office as he leaves. The scene shifts to a modestly furnished room, containing only a cheap bed, a chair or two, and a dresser. Mary lies asleep in the bed, undisturbed by the simplicity of their surroundings. As George enters the room, his mind is a whirlwind of confusing thoughts, each one tied to various incidents from his past life. He removes his hat and coat, placing them aside, and moves over to the dresser, where he pauses to stare at his reflection in the mirror. As these thoughts continue to swirl in his mind, his attention is drawn to a picture on the wall near the dresser. It is a sketch of George lassoing the moon, a familiar image first seen in Mary's living room. At this moment, Mary awakens and begins to sing their theme song, her voice filling the room. George crosses over to her, sitting on the edge of the bed, and Mary nods her head happily in response to his presence. In the subsequent series of shots, the voices of Joseph and Clarence can be heard from Heaven, providing a celestial commentary. George is seen crossing the street, making his way toward the offices of the Building and Loan. Meanwhile, Mary is seated on the floor, playing with a baby, while a little boy occupies a playpen nearby. She is also busy with the task of hanging wallpaper and painting the old place, her industriousness evident. George enters the hall, visibly tired and discouraged, and as he begins to ascend the stairs, the knob on the banister comes off in his hand, a small but frustrating setback. Elsewhere, a group of men, freshly drafted, are marching in a camp, their movements synchronized and purposeful. Mrs. Bailey, along with other women in Red Cross uniforms, is diligently sewing and attending to various tasks. Mary, equipped with a portable U.S.O. pushcart, is serving coffee and doughnuts to men leaning out from a train, her efforts bringing comfort to those in transit. Sam Wainwright is engaged in a discussion with two Army officers, showing them a set of blueprints, his demeanor confident and assured. Potter is wheeled toward a long table, around which several men are seated, ready to engage in serious discussion. Gower and Uncle Billy are energetically conducting a bond rally from atop an Army tank, their enthusiasm infectious. Bert, dressed in uniform, moves cautiously with a fixed bayonet, the background alive with smoke and flashes of gunfire, creating a scene of intense action. Overhead, hundreds of planes fill the sky, with parachutes dropping from them, a testament to the scale of the ongoing conflict. In the foreground, Marty beckons to soldiers, urging them to advance, while Harry is busy fastening the helmet of his flying clothes, preparing for the challenges ahead.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Potter, the wealthy but unscrupulous businessman notorious in the community for his ruthlessness, is lighting a big cigar which he has just given George, the owner of the local Building and Loan association, and the goon, Potter's loyal but intimidating bodyguard, is beside Potter's chair, as usual. George drops his cigar on his lap and nervously brushes off the sparks from his clothes. As they shake hands, George feels a physical revulsion because Potter's hand feels like a cold mackerel to him, reminiscent of unpleasant encounters in his past. In that moment of physical contact, he knows he could never be associated with this man and drops his hand with a shudder. He peers intently into Potter's face, a visage often seen in the local newspaper's business section, turns, and shouts at the goon, impassive as ever beside Potter's wheelchair, a symbol of his physical decline but enduring influence. As George opens the office door to exit, he shouts at Mr. Potter's secretary in the outer office, a woman who has worked for the company for over a decade. The room is modestly furnished with just a cheap bed, a chair or two, and a dresser, typical of the frugal lifestyle George maintains despite his important role in the community. Mary is asleep in the bed, unaware of George's tumultuous thoughts. As George comes in, his head is filled with many confusing thoughts relating to incidents in his past life, a journey marked by personal and financial struggles. George takes off his hat and coat, moves over to the dresser, and stares at his reflection in the mirror, contemplating the toll recent events have taken on him. While the above thoughts are passing through George's head, his attention is caught by a picture on the wall near the dresser, which is the sketch of George lassoing the moon that we first saw in Mary's living room, a testament to their shared dreams and aspirations. Mary is now awake and starts singing their theme song, a melody that has accompanied many of their cherished memories. George crosses over and sits on the edge of the bed, and Mary nods her head happily, finding comfort in his presence. Over the following series of shots, we hear the voices of Joseph and Clarence, celestial figures orchestrating George's life from Heaven. George is crossing the street, heading for the offices of the Building and Loan, the lifeline of many families in the town. Mary is sitting on the floor playing with a baby, and a little boy is in a playpen nearby, their children representing the continuation of their legacy. Mary is busy hanging wallpaper and painting the old place, an effort to revitalize their home despite financial constraints. George has just come into the hall. He is obviously tired and discouraged as he starts up the stairs, and the knob on the banister comes off in his hand, a recurring annoyance symbolizing the fragility of his circumstances. A group of men, obviously just drafted, are marching along in a camp, illustrating the community's contribution to the war efforts during these challenging times. Mrs. Bailey and other women in Red Cross uniforms are busily sewing, etc., playing a vital role in supporting the soldiers overseas. Mary, with a portable U.S.O. pushcart, is serving coffee and doughnuts to men leaning from the train, her way of offering comfort to soldiers departing for war. Sam Wainwright, an old friend and successful businessman, is showing a set of blueprints to two Army officers, likely related to his expanding manufacturing business contributing to the war effort. Potter is wheeled in toward a long table around which several men are seated, an image of his continued strategic meetings despite his health issues. Gower and Uncle Billy are conducting a bond rally from the top of an Army tank, encouraging the community to invest in the nation's security. Bert, in uniform, is moving cautiously with a fixed bayonet, and there are smoke and flashes of gunfire in the background, depicting his involvement in active combat. Hundreds of planes are flying overhead with parachutes dropping from them, a scene symbolic of the massive military operations occurring at the time. Marty is in the foreground, beckoning to soldiers to come on, and Harry is fastening the helmet of his flying clothes, preparing for his role as a heroic pilot in the ongoing war.

Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. Over the following series of shots we hear the voices of Joseph and Clarence in Heaven. George is crossing the street heading for the offices of the Building and Loan. Mary is sitting on the floor playing with a baby and a little boy is in a playpen nearby. Mary is busy hanging wallpaper and painting the old place. George has just come into the hall. He is obviously tired and discouraged as he starts up the stairs and the knob on the banister comes off in his hand. A group of men obviously just drafted are marching along in a camp. Mrs Bailey and other women in Red Cross uniforms are busily sewing etc. Mary with a portable USO pushcart is serving coffee and doughnuts to men leaning from the train. Sam Wainwright is showing a set of blueprints to two Army officers. Potter is wheeled in toward a long table around which several men are seated. Gower and Uncle Billy are conducting a bond rally from the top of an Army tank. Bert in uniform is moving cautiously with a fixed bayonet and there are smoke and flashes of gunfire in the background. Hundreds of planes are flying overhead with parachutes dropping from them Marty is in the foreground beckoning to soldiers to come on and Harry is fastening the helmet of his flying clothes.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: Potter is lighting a big cigar which he has just given George and the goon is beside Potter's chair as usual. George drops his cigar on his lap and nervously brushes off the sparks from his clothes. As they shake hands George feels a physical revulsion because Potter's hand feels like a cold mackerel to him. In that moment of physical contact he knows he could never be associated with this man and drops his hand with a shudder. He peers intently into Potter's face turns and shouts at the goon impassive as ever beside Potter's wheelchair. As George opens the office door to exit he shouts at Mr Potter's secretary in the outer office. The room is modestly furnished with just a cheap bed a chair or two and a dresser. Mrs Bailey and other women in Red Cross uniforms are busily sewing etc. Mary with a portable USO pushcart is serving coffee and doughnuts to men leaning from the train. Sam Wainwright is showing a set of blueprints to two Army officers. Potter is wheeled in toward a long table around which several men are seated. Gower and Uncle Billy are conducting a bond rally from the top of an Army tank. Bert in uniform is moving cautiously with a fixed bayonet and there are smoke and flashes of gunfire in the background. Hundreds of planes are flying overhead with parachutes dropping from them Marty is in the foreground beckoning to soldiers to come on and Harry is fastening the helmet of his flying clothes.

George drops his cigar on his lap and nervously brushes off the sparks from his clothes. As they shake hands George feels a physical revulsion because Potter's hand feels like a cold mackerel to him. Gower and Uncle Billy are conducting a bond rally from the top of an Army tank. Bert in uniform is moving cautiously with a fixed bayonet and there are smoke and flashes of gunfire in the background. Hundreds of planes are flying overhead with parachutes dropping from them Marty is in the foreground beckoning to soldiers to come on and Harry is fastening the helmet of his flying clothes.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Zookeeper is igniting a large candle which he has just handed to Jenny, and the clownfish is next to Zookeeper's hammock, as expected. Jenny tosses her candle onto her shoe and anxiously sweeps the petals from her outfit. As they high-five, Jenny experiences a mental reaction because Zookeeper's elbow feels like a frozen pineapple to her. In that encounter of mental touch, she realizes she could never partner with this individual and releases her elbow with a grimace. She peers curiously into Zookeeper's expression, swivels, and barks at the clownfish, blank as ever beside Zookeeper's skateboard. As Jenny slides the closet flap to retreat, she barks at Mr. Zookeeper's barber in the outer courtyard. The area is lavishly decorated with just a grand piano, a hammock or three, and a wardrobe. Lucy is dozing in the hammock. As Jenny enters, her mind is loaded with numerous bewildering memories concerning episodes in her past journeys. Jenny removes her scarf and mittens, ambles over to the wardrobe, and examines her figure in the portrait. While the aforementioned memories are flitting through Jenny's mind, her gaze is snagged by a diagram on the door near the wardrobe, which is the depiction of Jenny juggling the stars that we first observed in Lucy's den. Lucy is now alert and starts humming their favorite tune. Jenny traverses over and perches on the brink of the hammock, and Lucy bobs her chin joyfully. Over the succeeding sequence of pictures, we perceive the calls of Ben and Claudia in the Universe. Jenny is scooting the bridge, aiming for the chambers of the Library and Café. Lucy is sliding on the stage playing with a puppy, and a small kitten is in a crate nearby. Lucy is engrossed applying wallpaper and redecorating the new mansion. Jenny has just entered the grove. She is clearly drained and dispirited as she climbs up the ladder, and the bell on the railing detaches in her grip. A cluster of owls, evidently just recruited, are frolicking along in a forest. Mrs. Thomas and other chefs in Blue Apron costumes are briskly cooking, etc. Lucy, with a movable food cart, is offering tea and muffins to owls leaning from the boat. Paul Maple is presenting a set of maps to two Navy chefs. Zookeeper is rolled in toward a round counter around which several owls are lounging. Jenkins and Grandpa Bob are staging a dance jamboree from the peak of a Navy ship. Steve, in costume, is advancing cautiously with a pointed fishing rod, and there are bubbles and flashes of fireworks in the backdrop. Dozens of balloons are floating nearby with streamers cascading from them. Brenda is in the center stage, gesturing to bakers to proceed, and Mario is securing the visor of his skiing outfit.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: George receives a cigar from Potter but drops it, nervously brushing sparks off his clothes. He shakes hands with Potter, feeling revulsion at the cold, fish-like touch, realizing he can't associate with him. George exits, shouting at Potter's secretary, and returns to a modestly furnished room where Mary sleeps. Distracted by thoughts of his past, he looks at himself in the mirror and notices a sketch of himself lassoing the moon, which he saw in Mary's living room. Mary awakens, sings their theme song, and George sits on the bed beside her. Voices of Joseph and Clarence are heard as George heads to the Building and Loan office. Mary plays with a baby, and a boy is nearby while busy hanging wallpaper. George, tired and discouraged, arrives home and breaks a knob off the banister. Scenes show drafted men marching, Mrs. Bailey in Red Cross activities, Mary serving coffee and doughnuts to soldiers, Sam Wainwright showing blueprints to Army officers, Potter at a meeting, Gower and Uncle Billy rallying bonds, Bert in uniform, and planes flying overhead.
